docs.lead_paragraph: The World Bank recently released the results of its 2008 World Bank Group Entrepreneurship Survey. The results show something free marketers around the globe should appreciate. After accounting for differences in per capita income across countries, the World Bank researchers found that countries with easier and less expensive procedures for registering new businesses have higher rates of new business creation.

headline.main: An Easy Way to Encourage Entrepreneurship

docs.abstract: Making things simple for entrepreneurs and getting out of the way does a lot to encourage people to start their own companies.

docs.lead_paragraph: Imagine a restaurant with no prices on the menu. Or, better yet, no menu at all. The name of the place is ''Food'' or ''Eat Here,'' which is the only clue about what is sold inside. The chef decides what to cook, and what to charge. Do you sit?

headline.main: Need Medical Care? Check Out the Menu

docs.abstract: Senate Finance Committee health care bill has provision that for first time would require all hospitals to establish menu of charges, since patients often have no idea what medical treatment costs; government-run insurance plan favored by liberals would have doctors' fees tied to Medicare providers' rates; other public plan would negotiate rates with providers; analysts say public plan that negotiates rates would have limited ability to cut costs for consumers (M)
docs.snippet: Imagine a restaurant with no prices on the menu. Or, better yet, no menu at all. The name of the place is ''Food'' or ''Eat Here,'' which is the only clue about what is sold inside. The chef decides what to cook, and what to charge.      Do you sit?

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON - Imagine a restaurant with no prices on the menu. Or, better yet, no menu at all. The name of the place is "Food" or "Eat Here," which is the only clue about what is sold inside. The chef decides what to cook, and what to charge.

headline.main: Need Medical Care? Check Out the Menu

docs.abstract: Tucked away on Page 251 of the Senate Finance Committee's 1,502-page health care bill is a remarkable little provision that for the first time would require all hospitals in the United States to establish a menu, a list of "standard charges for items and services."
